summary.text: "'Here you must banish all distrust, / here must all cowardice be slain. / 'We have come to where I said / you would see the miserable sinners / who have lost the good of the intellect.'" (Lines 14-18)

After entering Hell, they encounter sinners running after a banner, punished "by stinging flies and wasps / that made their faces stream with blood" (Lines 66-67). Dante recognizes one of the souls as the one "who, through cowardice, made the great refusal" (Line 60).

At the shore, they meet Charon the demon ferrying sinners across the river. Charon tells Dante "By another way, another port, / not here, you'll come to shore and cross" (Lines 91-92). Virgil assures Charon this is "willed where will and power are one" (Line 95). Charon agrees, and Dante faints as they cross.

text.name: CHARON
text.desc: Charon is a character in Greek Mythology whose job is to ferry people across the river Acheron and enter the underworld. In this case, Dante places him at the entrance of Hell as a demon who ferries sinners to their punishment in Hell.

text.name: POPE CELESTINE V
text.desc: He was the predecessor to Pope Boniface VIII who was Dante’s enemy. The Pope became pope at 80 and, while a very spiritual man, was not proficient at administrative work. He led the church to become dependent on King Charles II of Naples and resigned leaving the papal throne to Pope Boniface VIII.

analysis.title: POLITICS
analysis.text: The sinners at the shore of Hell are punished for being unable to pick sides when they were alive. In line 60, Dante recognizes (who many interpretations believe to be) Pope Celestine V as one of these sinners: the man “who, through cowardice, made the great refusal.” The pope’s abdication to Boniface is seen as “cowardice”, and Dante sees his lack of action during his papal term as giving way to corruption within the Church. We will see especially as we continue on the journey that politics plays a very large role in how Dante views the spiritual and physical world.

analysis.title: THE CONTRAPASSO
analysis.text: The punishment assigned to the sinners is often a portrayal of divine retribution. For the sinners who could not pick a side in life, they are damned to running around chasing a meaningless banner around representing their inability to stay with one side. The flies and wasps that sting at/stimulate their bodies because in life they lacked the inner stimulation inside to fight for their causes. Their punishment reflects their indecision and lack of moral commitment in life.

analysis.title: MYTH vs. FAITH
analysis.text: Charon, the ferryman, is a character from Greek mythology who guides souls into the underworld. He did not exist in the Bible, and yet Dante the Poet uses him at the entrance of Hell. He even plays a somewhat similar role where he is ferrying sinners to their punishment in Hell. The difference, however, is that sinners Charon the Greek myth ferried had a chance at bliss whereas sinners Charon ferries over in Inferno are damned to suffer for eternity. It is also important to note that while Charon is a character from Greek myth, he still obeys God. On lines 95-96, Virgil tells Chiron “​It is so willed where will and power are one, / and ask no more” when he protested Dante coming by his boat and “That stilled the shaggy jowls” (Line 97). His obedience to God reminds us that even though Dante integrates pagan characters into his writing by having them take important roles, they are written to assist God, not to detract from him. By using these pagan characters, Dante the poet is able to ground his christian spiritual journey in common cultural references.

analysis.title: DANTE FAINTING
analysis.text: Dante the pilgrim fainting serves three purposes. First, it reminds readers that he is a living human in need of guidance. An example of this is when he remarks “I could not believe / death had undone so many” (Lines 56-57). He is too mentally weak to fully grasp divine retribution which is overwhelming suffering. As a human, he is also more relatable to the readers as someone who is not numb to the horrors he will experience. Second, it helps us establish character growth. At the start of Hell, the sights and sounds of the sinners suffering is enough to overwhelm him both with horror and pity. By the end of Inferno, we will see that Dante has grown in dealing with what he sees and understanding divine retribution. His character growth is very important because as Dante the pilgrim grows spiritually through asking Virgil questions, readers also learn more about how Dante the poet interprets the Bible and how they can apply that interpretation to their own lives. Third, by fainting, Dante the poet does not have to deal with details like how he got across the river. Just like the whitespace transition between his decision to enter Hell and his actual entry to Hell, there is a whitespace transition in between standing on the shore of the river Acheron and entering the first circle of Hell.
